prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my friend she’s still single due to having 5 babies by different fathers?
She finished her 5th divorce two years ago, and for these two years she keeps asking me questions that also insult me.

 “How did you get a man at 30 with kids? It’s because you’re so skinny.” 

“Do I have to stop eating like you? Haha haha”

“You has so many dates. Guys only want basic blondes who are girly.”

“Did you only talk about sex with them?!”

For two years I’ve brushed off the insults, and replied: “ You’re in a small town” or “focus on yourself , and someone special will come around”

Finally she asks for the billionth time “How did you get any dates at 30 with kids?!? You don’t even have a real job! Tell me the truth- why can’t I get anyone?”

I replied honestly and said: “ You have five kids with different dads and none of them pay child support. It’s going to be hard for someone to accept that when you openly are looking for a father figure.”

This launched her into an insult fury, and she hung up on me. 

For reference: I’m not skinny but I work out (healthy weight). I eat more than her, honestly, not starving. I’m girly about some things I guess. I have two kids by the same dad and we split custody 50/50. I work in the adult industry, but only need to put in 8-10 hours a week to make a way better than average income. She keeps insulting my work even though she tried to do it, as well. I also have a vanilla job and an MBA. 

I was tired of being hit low quality and untrue insults, so I replied with what I thought was the truth.

Now, all of our mutual friends are saying I have skinny privilege and such. I’m entitled and don’t understand what she’s going through. They said it was messed up to say that and I’m a shitty friend, and I get whatever I want. She’s not going through anything that major. She’s just dating and being a mom like I had to do. 

Now I’m stuck with my mouth shut, and I’m mad at everyone because I’m not privileged or entitled at all- I’ve worked very hard for anything and everything I have.  And side note- the girl keeps talking about her

AITA for saying that? Was there a better thing to say? 
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the person who wrote this is in the wrong for telling their friend that her being single is because she has five kids by different fathers. Let me break this down.

First, the friend has a history of making hurtful comments and insults towards the author. The author tried to brush them off, giving advice like focusing on oneself. But when the friend continued to pester with more insults and questions, the author finally responded honestly, pointing out her situation with the kids and child support. The friend was upset, hung up, and now mutual friends are criticizing the author for being entitled or having privilege.

So, the main issue here is whether the author's response was appropriate. The friend was being rude and judgmental, so the author felt justified in calling out the friend's behavior. But friends are saying the author was wrong. The question is, was the author in the wrong?

On one hand, the author was responding to years of insults and felt that their friend was projecting her own issues onto them. The author's comment was a factual observation that having multiple children with different fathers without child support could make it hard to find someone. But on the other hand, even if the statement is true, the way it was delivered might have been harsh, especially in the context of a friendship where the friend was already sensitive about her situation. The author's tone and the fact that they were being defensive could have made it come off as judgmental rather than supportive.

Also, the mutual friends' reactions might be pointing out that the author's response could be seen as privileged or not understanding the friend's struggles, even if the author is working hard themselves. The friend's history of making personal, insulting remarks might have contributed to a toxic dynamic where the author's defense was a reaction to being attacked.

In terms of whether it's right or wrong, it's a bit nuanced. The author had a right to set boundaries after repeated insults, but the response might have been too direct in a way that didn't consider the friend's feelings. A better approach might have been to address the friend's behavior without directly accusing her of the root cause of her situation. Maybe focusing on how the friend's comments were hurtful rather than pointing out her flaws. So, the author might be in the wrong for how they handled it, even if the underlying truth is valid.
